+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| The Argument For F/OSS In Schools                                  |
|   from the teaching-freedom dept.                                  |
|   posted by kdawson on Tuesday June 12, @21:06 (Education)         |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/12/2153223              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]pfaffman sends us word of a two-part article in LinuxInsider that lays
out to an audience of non-tech educators a [1]cogent argument for
[2]using F/OSS in schools. The piece was written by a University of
Tennessee professor for the education journal TechTrends. It makes the
case that proprietary software is inconvenient and that when schools
choose to use proprietary products they spend their constituents' money.
The article won't contain a whole lot of surprises for Linux initiates
(save perhaps some software recommendations for educational use), but
it's interesting to see these ideas presented so clearly to a wider, and
influential, audience."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/12/2153223

Links:
    0. http://learn.occ.utk.edu/
    1. http://www.linuxinsider.com/story/57759.html
    2. http://www.linuxinsider.com/story/57760.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| TV's "Mr. Wizard," Don Herbert, Dies At 89                         |
|   from the so-long-and-thanks-for-all-the-experiments dept.        |
|   posted by kdawson on Tuesday June 12, @22:30 (Television)        |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/0149234      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]XorNand writes "[1]Television's Mr. Wizard, Don Herbert, died today at
89. He introduced generations of young viewers to the joys of science.
Herbert, who had bone cancer, died at his suburban Bell Canyon home near
Los Angeles."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/0149234

Links:
    0. http://blog.rightbrainnetworks.com/
    1. http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/tv/1401AP_Obit_Herbert.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| NC Man Fined For Using Vegetable Oil As Fuel                       |
|   from the can't-believe-it's-not-butter dept.                     |
|   posted by kdawson on Tuesday June 12, @23:55 (It's funny.  Laugh.|
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/12/2238213     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]mdsolar writes "The News and Observer reports on an Charlotte, NC
driver who has been [1]fined $1000 for not paying a fuel tax when he
fills his tank with vegetable oil. Perhaps the funniest quote is this
one: '"With the high cost of fuel right now, the department does
recognize that a lot of people are looking for relief," said Reggie
Little, assistant director of the motor fuel taxes division. "We're not
here to hurt the small guy, we're just trying to make sure that the
playing field is level."' Sure, since the field is so plainly tilted
against Arab oil interests."

Discuss this story at:
    http://hardware.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/12/2238213

Links:
    0. http://www.jointhesolution.com/mdsolar
    1. http://www.newsobserver.com/news/story/599471.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Can Statistics Predict the Outcome of a War?                       |
|   from the first-you-have-to-get-the-inputs-right dept.            |
|   posted by kdawson on Wednesday June 13, @02:53 (Math)            |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/12/2213233      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

StatisticallyDeadGuy writes "A University of Georgia scientist has
developed a statistical system that can, she claims, [0]predict the
outcome of wars with an accuracy of 80 percent. Her approach, applied
retrospectively, says the US chance of victory in the first Gulf War was
93%, while the poor Soviets only had a 7% chance in Afghanistan (if only
they'd known; failure maybe triggered the collapse of the USSR). As for
the current Iraq conflict: the US started off with a 70% chance of a
successful regime change, which was duly achieved \u2014 but extending the
mission past this to support a weak government has dropped the
probability of ultimate success to 26%. [1]Full elaboration of the
forecasting methodology is laid out in a new paper (subscription required
\u2014 link goes to the abstract). Some details can be gleaned from her
[2]2006 draft (PDF)."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/12/2213233

Links:
    0. http://www.uga.edu/news/artman/publish/printer_070611_Sullivan.shtml
    1. http://jcr.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/51/3/496
    2. http://www.cas.sc.edu/poli/psrw/Sullivan031703.pdf


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Closed Source On Linux and BSD?                                    |
|   from the license-ramification-details dept.                      |
|   posted by kdawson on Wednesday June 13, @05:36 (Linux)           |
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/023234         |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "I want to start (very small)
software/hardware business. The code in question will be closed source. I
won't modify or use any GPL code or any 3rd-party sources. It will be my
own handwritten C/C++ code from start to finish. I am planning to sell
embedded-like boxes with an OS (Linux or BSD) and this code. I am more
familiar with Linux but I am scared a little bit of Linux licensing, and
also of Linux fanboy-ism: I personally got a 'go to hell with your @#$
closed code' slur on Slashdot. I am not a GPL guru and not a software
freedom fighter. I just want to do my job and make a living." Read on for
this reader's five particular questions.

This story continues at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/023234

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/023234


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Building a Data Center In 60 Days                                  |
|   from the 170-racks-and-nothin'-on dept.                          |
|   posted by kdawson on Wednesday June 13, @08:11 (The Internet)    |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/0233233           |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]miller60 writes "The facilities team at Australia's Pipe Networks is
down to the wire in its bid to [1]complete a data center in 60 days. And
in an era when many major data-center projects are shrouded in secrecy,
these guys are putting the entire effort online, with daily updates and
photos on the [2]company blog, a [3]live webcam inside the facility, a
countdown timer, and a punch-list of key tasks left to finish. Their goal
is to complete the job by Friday morning eastern US time."

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/0233233

Links:
    0. http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/
    1. http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2007/Jun/12/building_a_data_center_in_60_days.html
    2. http://www.pipenetworks.com/dc3/index.php
    3. http://www.pipenetworks.com/dc3/static.php?page=webcam


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Torvalds vs Schwartz GPL Wars                                      |
|   from the which-one-is-han-solo dept.                             |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Wednesday June 13, @08:58 (Sun Microsystems|
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1224201        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]javipas writes "The [1]controversial message published by Linus
Torvalds ([2]mirrored) in the Linux Kernel Mailing List was from the
beginning to the end an open attack to Sun and its Open Source strategy.
Linus criticized Sun's real position on GPL, and claimed that Linux could
be dangerous to Sun. Upon his words, "they may be talking a lot more
[about Open Source] than they are or ever will be doing." [3]Jonathan
Schwartz's blog has been updated today with a post that is a direct
response to Linus claims, but in a much more elegant and coherent way.
Sun's CEO notes that "Companies compete, communities simply fracture",
and tries to explain why using GPL licenses is taking so long."

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1224201

Links:
    0. http://www.javipas.com/
    1. http://lkml.org/lkml/2007/6/12/232
    2. http://www.ussg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0706.1/1722.html
    3. http://blogs.sun.com/jonathan/entry/one_plus_one_is_fifty


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Yahoo Rejects Anti-Censorship Proposal                             |
|   from the didn't-know-yahoo-was-still-even-in-business dept.      |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Wednesday June 13, @09:44 (Censorship)     |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1315230          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Matthew Skala writes "The BBC reports that [1]Yahoo! has rejected a
shareholder proposal to adopt an anti-censorship policy, as well as one
to set up a human rights committee to review the impact of Yahoo!'s
operations in places like China. The interesting proposals are numbers
[2]6 and [3]7 in the [4]proxy statement available through EDGAR. This
news comes on the heels of jailed Chinese reporter Shi Tao, [5]suing
Yahoo! for its involvement in his conviction, and Google's [6]rejection
of a similar proposal. The anti-censorship proposal was submitted by the
same groups (several New York City pension funds) as the Google proposal.
The proxy statement also includes the Board's recommendations \u2014 "strongly
oppose[ing]" both proposals \u2014 with explanations of their reasoning."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1315230

Links:
    0. http://ansuz.sooke.bc.ca/bonobo-conspiracy/?r=sd
    1. http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6747095.stm
    2. http://sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1011006/000089161807000262/f29344dedef14a.htm#009
    3. http://sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1011006/000089161807000262/f29344dedef14a.htm#010
    4. http://sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1011006/000089161807000262/f29344dedef14a.htm
    5. http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/10/AR2007061000827.html
    6. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/11/0416216&tid=217


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Safari 3 vs. Firefox 2 and IE7                                     |
|   from the not-worth-it dept.                                      |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Wednesday June 13, @10:37 (The Internet)   |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1349202              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Bobcat writes "Ars Technica has a 'first look' at Safari for Windows,
which is interesting because it's written from the [0]perspective of
someone new to Safari. It was tested against Firefox 2 and IE7 and aside
from the slightly faster page loading, Ars didn't find much to recommend
it to Windows users. 'The modest increase in rendering performance is
hardly worth the deficiencies, and Safari's user interface simply doesn't
provide the usability or flexibility of competing products. If the folks
at Apple think that providing Windows users with a taste of Mac OS X
through Safari is going to entice them to buy a Mac, it's going to take a
better effort than the Safari 3 beta. Even if the final release is more
polished and completely bug-free, it still won't be as powerful or
feature-loaded as Opera or Firefox.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1349202

Links:
    0. http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070612-afirst-look-safari-3-on-windows.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| What Happens If You Don't Pay for Goodmail?                        |
|   from the something-to-think-about dept.                          |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Wednesday June 13, @11:26 (Communications) |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1420205              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Bennett Haselton has written in with his latest report. He starts
"Goodmail has [1]announced partnerships with four new ISPs who will
charge for "reliable" delivery of your e-mail messages if you want to
bypass their spam filters. The news will probably generate another round
of editorials like the ones written a year ago about AOL's plan to use
Goodmail, including [2]this one from Esther Dyson (for it) and [3]this
one from the EFF (against it)." Follow the magical clicky clicker below
to read the rest of this story.

This story continues at:
    http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1420205

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1420205

Links:
    0. mailto:bennett@peacefire.org
    1. http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070606/ap_on_hi_te/techbit_e_mail_fee;_ylt=AjpFr0DQnEBQwxU4QFwC1K3MWM0F
    2. http://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/17/opinion/17dyson.html?ex=1300251600&en=04138dcf8237c907&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss%20%20
    3. http://www.eff.org/deeplinks/archives/004398.php


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Yahoo Confirms Beijing Blocking Flickr                             |
|   from the well-isn't-this-awkward dept.                           |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Wednesday June 13, @12:19 (Censorship)     |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1522234          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]slashthedot writes "In another instance of censorship against websites
about anything anti-establishment in China, Flickr, popular among a
growing class of digital photo enthusiasts in the world's second-largest
Internet market, [1]has not shown photos to users in mainland China since
last week, amid [2]rumors Beijing took action after images of the
Tiananmen massacre in early June 1989 were posted. "It is our
understanding that Flickr users in China are not able to see images on
Flickr, and we have confirmed that this is not a technical issue on our
end," a spokeswoman for Yahoo Hong Kong said in an email in response to a
Reuters inquiry."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1522234

Links:
    0. http://osgeek.blogspot.com/
    1. http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?alias=yahoo-says-beijing-likely&chanId=sa003&modsrc=reuters
    2. http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/09/1914226&tid=153


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Matter Discovered Traveling at Near Light Speed                    |
|   from the celestial-slingshot dept.                               |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @13:08 (Space)     |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1552224      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]mcgrew writes to mention New Scientist is reporting that scientists
have clocked matter traveling at [1]99.999% the speed of light. "The
fastest flows of matter in the universe shoot out of dying stars at more
than 99.999% the speed of light, new observations reveal. When a massive
star runs out of fuel, it collapses to form a black hole or a neutron
star. In the process, some of the matter from the star also explodes
outward at blistering speeds, producing an intense burst of gamma rays
and other radiation."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1552224

Links:
    0. mailto:sm62704@yahoo.com
    1. http://space.newscientist.com/article/dn12051-jets-of-matter-clocked-at-nearlight-speed.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| FBI Releases Results of Operation Bot Roast                        |
|   from the notification-flagged-as-spam-and-deleted dept.          |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @13:57 (Security)  |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/178212            |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]coondoggie writes to tell us that the FBI has released the findings of
their recent botnet study and have identified over [1]1 million botnet
crime victims. "The FBI is working with industry partners, including the
Computer Emergency Response Team Coordination Center at Carnegie Mellon
University, to notify the victim owners of the computers. Microsoft and
the Botnet Task Force have also helped out the FBI. Through this process
the FBI may uncover additional incidents in which botnets have been used
to facilitate other criminal activity, the FBI said in a statement.Bots
are widely recognized as one of the top scourges of the industry. Gartner
predicts that by year-end 75% of enterprises 'will be infected with
undetected, financially motivated, targeted malware that evaded
traditional perimeter and host defenses.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/178212

Links:
    0. http://networkworld.com/
    1. http://www.networkworld.com/community/?q=node/16193


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Linux Programmer's Toolbox                                         |
|   from the open-the-box dept.                                      |
|   posted by samzenpus on Wednesday June 13, @14:45 (Book Reviews)  |
|   http://books.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1454241        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Ravi writes "What does it take to start writing programs for Linux?
Most people will guess a text editor, knowledge of a programming
language, the compiler and libraries of that language. Ask a professional
programmer and he will differ with you. Insisting that while those things
can help get you started, other things come into play in writing
efficient programs such as, a debugger, memory profiler tools and above
all a good understanding of the inner working of the Linux kernel and its
processes." Read below for the rest of Ravi's review.

This story continues at:
    http://books.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/1454241

Discuss this story at:
    http://books.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/1454241

Links:
    0. http://linuxhelp.blogspot.com/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Plants 'Recognize' Their Siblings                                  |
|   from the family-tree dept.                                       |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @15:36 (Science)   |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/191227       |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes to tell us that according to a recent study,
Biologists have found that plants are able to [0]recognize their own
relatives. "Researchers at McMaster University have found that plants get
fiercely competitive when forced to share their pot with strangers of the
same species, but they're accommodating when potted with their siblings.
[...] Though they lack cognition and memory, the study shows plants are
capable of complex social behaviours such as altruism towards relatives,
says Dudley. Like humans, the most interesting behaviours occur beneath
the surface."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/191227

Links:
    0. http://pressesc.com/01181755074_plants_recognise_siblings


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| What Microsoft Could Learn from OSS and Linux                      |
|   from the they-seem-to-be-doing-ok dept.                          |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @16:25 (Microsoft) |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/2013222              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "An article on OSWeekly.com discusses a few
things that [0]Microsoft could learn from OSS and Linux. 'As Microsoft
continues to understand that open source does not mean they cannot
generate a decent profit, I honestly wonder if they will eventually "get"
that releasing MS Office code to the open source community is their only
option. Since the whole threatening to sue thing will be met with the
same fan base response, just like the RIAA, it is certainly not a wise
decision. And if Microsoft thinks Open Office is a pain now, try suing
people over it, then see how many people refuse to buy their products.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/2013222

Links:
    0. http://www.osweekly.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2575&Itemid=449


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Europe Unveils New Space Plane for Tourist Market                  |
|   from the another-toy-for-the-elite dept.                         |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @17:17 (Space)     |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/2045232      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]mrminator writes to tell us Space.com is reporting that Europe's
largest space contractor, EADS, has just announced their plans to build a
[1]new space tourism vehicle. The new rocket, powered by liquid methane
and liquid oxygen will carry passengers on a 90 minute round trip flight
for somewhere in the neighborhood of 200,000 euros ($267,000).

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/2045232

Links:
    0. mailto:mattiem@gmail.com
    1. http://www.space.com/businesstechnology/AstriumEadsweb_061307.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| AT&T Announces Plans to Filter Copyright Content               |
|   from the bad-idea dept.                                          |
|   posted by ScuttleMonkey on Wednesday June 13, @18:06 (The Interne|
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/2057251          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "The LA Times reports that AT&T has announced
plans to work with the Hollywood movie studios and major recording labels
to implement [0]new content filtering systems on their network. The plans
raise many [1]troubling legal issues including privacy concerns, false
positive filtering, and liability for failure to filter."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/2057251

Links:
    0. http://www.latimes.com/business/printedition/la-fi-piracy13jun13,1,402794.story?coll=la-headlines-pe-business
    1. http://www.michaelgeist.ca/content/view/2023/125/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| ISS Goes Solar                                                     |
|   from the no-clouds-in-space dept.                                |
|   posted by samzenpus on Wednesday June 13, @19:29 (Space)         |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/13/2222248      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]SumDog writes "The international space station's newest power source,
[1] a set of solar wings, made its debut yesterday. The solar array is
part of a new 17.5-ton space station segment that was connected to the
orbiting outpost during a spacewalk Monday."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/06/13/2222248

Links:
    0. http://penguindreams.org/
    1. http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/06/13/space_station_solar_panels_make_debut_shuttle_repair_eyed/
